CatDescriptText: Betty Bullard, housewife, 2001 Bedford Avenue and Lawrence Coleman, taxicab driver, Hill District, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, June 4, 1960, pg. A1 with question "Do you think there is immediate danger of a third world war?  Why? If so, whom do you think our allies will be?"  Mrs. Bullard's answer reads: "Yes, things are bad.  And it didn't help matters for that sneak to get caught.  He had no business over there.  If there is a war, it will be rough on both sides."  Mr. Coleman's answer reads: "No, I feel that both sides have as much fear as the other and neither one wants to go to war."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Betty [or Margaret] Bullard wearing gingham sun dress with rick rack trim, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown; Portrait of Lawrence Coleman seated with arm out of window in drivers seat of taxicab
